holdings.text: There is no lis between parties in the appointment of trustees under section 15 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is hardly necessary to say that in this case the respondent had no right to be appointed a trustee nor had any of the other persons who were appointed trustees. There was no question of a proposition and an opposition. There is, therefore, no question of any lis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No applicant has a right to appointment as trustee; no proposition by one party opposed by another; no contest between authority and subject affecting rights.

holdings.text: Provisions of the Act do not require authorities appointing trustees under section 15 to act judicially.

anchor.surface_text: An examination of the provisions of the statute, which is an Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to the administration and government of charitable and Hindu religious institutions and endowments does not show that in appointing trustees to temples the concerned authorities have to act judicially. Nor is the appointment of trustees under section 15 left to the administrative authority without any guidelines laid down by the Legislature for being followed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute provides guidelines in sections 15 and 16 (due regard to denomination, founder wishes, disqualifications) but no requirement for judicial procedure, evidence, or weighing merits; discretionary appointment.

holdings.text: Revision powers under section 82 do not render appointments under section 15(1)(a) quasi-judicial.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that the fact that under section 82 of the Act the Commissioner has got the power of revision in respect of orders passed by his subordinates and the Government in respect of orders passed by the Commissioner as well as his subordinates there is no provision in the Act for a judicial review in respect of the orders passed by the Government in any way limits their powers under section 15 1 a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revision by superiors is administrative oversight; absence of judicial review confirms administrative nature; does not impose judicial duty on primary authority.

holdings.text: High Court erred in holding appointments under section 15 quasi-judicial requiring speaking order.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the learned Judges of the High Court were in error insofar as the implication of their observation is that in exercising their powers under sections 15 the administrative authorities concerned are exercising quasi-judicial functions and that it was necessary to have a speaking order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fails three-fold test (no lis, no objective satisfaction required, no duty to act judicially); administrative discretion guided by statute; no need for reasons distinguishing candidates.

holdings.text: Appointments of non-hereditary trustees under section 15 valid for better administration notwithstanding hereditary trustee.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in K. A. Samajam v. Commr, H. R. E. 1 dealing with this very section 15, that the power to appoint non-hereditary trustees or executive officers under ss. 15 and 27, even where there is already a hereditary trustee or trustees, notwithstanding that there is no mismanagement, is only for the purposes of ensuring better and efficient administration and management of the institution or endowment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following binding precedent in K.A. Samajam; due regard to denomination and founder wishes; declines to reconsider.

holdings.text: Appointment under section 15 administrative akin to section 47 Madras HRE Act 1959.

anchor.surface_text: We find that the madras Court in Commissioner, H.R. C.E. v. B. R. Venkatachalapathi after a very elaborate and instructive discussion has taken a similar view in respect of the powers of appointment of non-hereditary trustees under section 47 of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1959, which more or less corresponds to section 15 of this Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous provisions; Madras High Court correctly held administrative not quasi-judicial after detailed analysis.

anchor.surface_text: An examination of the provisions of the statute, which is an Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to the administration and government of charitable and Hindu religious institutions and endowments does not show that in appointing trustees to temples the concerned authorities have to act judicially. Nor is the appointment of trustees under section 15 left to the administrative authority without any guidelines laid down by the Legislature for being followed.

An examination of the provisions of the statute, which is an Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to the administration and government of charitable and Hindu religious institutions and endowments does not show that in appointing trustees to temples the concerned authorities have to act judicially. Nor is the appointment of trustees under section 15 left to the administrative authority without any guidelines laid down by the Legislature for being followed.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that the fact that under section 82 of the Act the Commissioner has got the power of revision in respect of orders passed by his subordinates and the Government in respect of orders passed by the Commissioner as well as his subordinates there is no provision in the Act for a judicial review in respect of the orders passed by the Government in any way limits their powers under section 15 1 a .

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the learned Judges of the High Court were in error insofar as the implication of their observation is that in exercising their powers under sections 15 the administrative authorities concerned are exercising quasi-judicial functions and that it was necessary to have a speaking order.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the learned Judges of the High Court were in error insofar as the implication of their observation is that in exercising their powers under sections 15 the administrative authorities concerned are exercising quasi-judicial functions and that it was necessary to have a speaking order.

This Court has held in K. A. Samajam v. Commr, H. R. E. 1 dealing with this very section 15, that the power to appoint non-hereditary trustees or executive officers under ss. 15 and 27, even where there is already a hereditary trustee or trustees, notwithstanding that there is no mismanagement, is only for the purposes of ensuring better and efficient administration and management of the institution or endowment.

This Court has held in K. A. Samajam v. Commr, H. R. E. 1 dealing with this very section 15, that the power to appoint non-hereditary trustees or executive officers under ss. 15 and 27, even where there is already a hereditary trustee or trustees, notwithstanding that there is no mismanagement, is only for the purposes of ensuring better and efficient administration and management of the institution or endowment.

We find that the madras Court in Commissioner, H.R. C.E. v. B. R. Venkatachalapathi after a very elaborate and instructive discussion has taken a similar view in respect of the powers of appointment of non-hereditary trustees under section 47 of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1959, which more or less corresponds to section 15 of this Act.
